critique: This executive order pertains to the free transportation of certain employees of The Panama Canal or the Panama Railroad Company upon termination of their service during World War II. It authorizes the Governor of The Panama Canal to furnish free transportation to a port or airport of the United States, with some conditions. It is difficult to assess the ideological tilt, immigration approach, security vs. liberty, economic regulation, and social inclusion aspects of this order as it mainly deals with logistical arrangements for employees during wartime. The order grants authority to the Governor of The Panama Canal, which could be seen as a slight expansion of executive power within that specific context. It also appears to centralize decision-making regarding transportation with the Governor, suggesting a move towards federal control in this limited area.
